title: What type of impact has technology had on interpersonal communication? - Quora

response.answer_text: It is a tricky question because from the first glimpse it appeared to me that technology has affected interpersonal communication only in a destructive way. But to be objective, there are pros and cons, and it is your turn to decide, what side to choose. Positive impact Instead of calling a person or arrange a personal meeting, we all have an opportunity to chat and solve one-minute-questions without wasting our time on optional social norms.It is now more possible to preserve distance relationships with people, no more carrier pigeons:) The ways we can communicate with the ones who are far away have broadened.Technology made communication rapid and easy. We are now able to get the news extremely fast. And if something bad happens, we can track our closest ones and take the right measure (of course with them knowing they’re tracked).Negative influence The quality of the conversations and overall face-to-face communication degraded. We get distracted by our phone notifications and chats even on family gatherings and friend meetings. For a lot of civilized people, it sounds devastating to put a phone down for a little while, filter annoying push notifications, and concentrate on the present.People share too much information and there is no strict line of what is personal, and what is not. We give too much information to people we barely know. The magic of discovering another person’s interests or the way of thinking has turned into silent surfing through the profiles of others.We create an ideal picture of ourselves on the Internet. Sometimes it looks like a competition - who’s happier, who’s richer, this list may last forever. We tend to think that all these profiles and pictures of bloggers/celebrities are a real reflection of somebody’s life. And feel broken, not good enough, not worthy enough.The dialogue has turned to monologue. We send or record our messages, knowing that we may not get the feedback in a quite amount of time. I feel like people now are more about sharing than listening, commenting than participating in a live discussion. The worst invention is voice recordings in messengers, it is lifeless and robotic. Instead of a real dialogue, we get recorded messages, also most people overuse this tool which makes the online conversations unbearable.We have all became robot-alike, with all the technologies rushing into our lives, let’s preserve our human nature and use the innovations wisely.

Is not technology seting people apart, is people dividing people, and some people may use (even at a subconcient level) the technology as a tool to be apart from other people, the blame here should not be on technology, technology has no agenda, should be on people. Image sourced from Google This is an envelope. You write letters by hand (or typing), put it in the envelope, buy stamps and send it through the post office. A few years back, this was the most affordable means of communication as telephone calls were quite expensive. However, it could take weeks or even months just go get delivered to the person your sending to. Oh yeah, and if by then they had moved or changed address, your letter may be lost like that. Plus you had no way to confirm if they received it. So you just had to wait hopefully and in a few weeks, or months, you would get your reply back.  Image sourced from Google This is a Nokia 3310. Around a decade back, phones of this type were the most common in most households. Owners could send instant messages (texts) and voice calls to others who owned similar phones. Nowadays, people consider this “outdated” and not many people would even think of buying such a phone.  Image sourced from Google This is the modern day phone, a smart phone. This is the normal phone to own these days and some are even available for as low as $50. Aside from texting and voice calls as the Nokia 3310 above, you have a whole tonne other features. Haven't seen your parents in a while? You can video call them and chat face to face. Baby taking those first steps? You can snap that picture or record a video and send it to your friends. You can also keep in touch with your work mates on the go and submit that project you've been working on at home to your boss. As technology is evolving, more and more features are being added to these smart phones and with it, the world is becoming “smaller and smaller”. You can connect with a person from the opposite side of the world effortlessly and cheaply now. Plus it all happens instantly.
